title: AHA Scientific Statement 2026: Early Recognition and Intervention for Poststroke Spasticity

recommendations.text: Spasticity can emerge within the first month after stroke and worsen over 6-12 months; early recognition and timely intervention are essential.
Use structured clinical rating scales and, when needed, electrophysiologic or biomechanical tools to quantify spasticity and monitor response.
Botulinum toxin (BoNT-A) consistently reduces tone; early use with optimized dosing and ultrasound guidance improves outcomes.
Intrathecal baclofen is effective for generalized spasticity but requires monitoring for adverse effects.
Selective dorsal rhizotomy can be effective in lower extremity spasticity in selected patients.
Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation is effective in lower limbs; duration of effect and upper-limb efficacy are less clear.
Phenol or alcohol nerve blocks provide temporary tone reduction and are options when BoNT-A is unavailable or ineffective.
Oral antispasticity agents (e.g., baclofen, tizanidine) offer modest tone reduction but are often limited by systemic side effects.
Selective motor neurectomy is an invasive option with longer-lasting effects and limited availability.
Cryoneurolysis has emerging evidence for sustained tone reduction; more research is needed.
Task-specific training improves motor control and function.
Constraint-induced movement therapy promotes use of the affected limb and is best suited for higher-functioning patients.
Functional electrical stimulation enhances voluntary activation; effects depend on timing and limb.
Noninvasive brain stimulation (rTMS/tDCS) is effective for upper-limb motor control; strongest evidence for anodal tDCS and low-frequency rTMS.
Repetitive peripheral magnetic stimulation can reduce tone; protocols need further refinement.
Bimanual training supports interlimb coordination; more robust trials are needed.
Music-supported therapy shows encouraging early evidence for motor function via auditory-motor coupling.
Robotic therapy facilitates repetitive task-specific training and may be most effective as adjunct to conventional therapy.
Vagal nerve stimulation paired with therapy improves upper extremity motor scores.
Aerobic and endurance training can improve motor control and counter inactivity effects.
Early mobilization and weight-bearing interventions help prevent contractures and reduce hyperreflexia when started early.
Passive stretching alone is not effective; combine with other rehabilitation modalities.
Static stretching with positioning orthoses provides modest tone improvements; evidence is limited by small studies.
Dry needling has short-term benefit in lower limbs; effects diminish over weeks.
Extracorporeal shockwave therapy reduces tone short-term; radial therapy may be superior.
Whole-body vibration can reduce spasticity, with strongest evidence in lower limbs using low-frequency protocols.
Localized muscle vibration improves tone in elbow or wrist; long-term and lower-limb data are limited.
Serial casting can temporarily prevent contractures but is labor intensive.
Soft tissue interventions (e.g., massage, myofascial release) have limited evidence and are typically adjunctive.
Hyaluronidase shows emerging benefit for tone and range of motion in subacute or chronic spasticity.
